review.title: A solution concept for games with altruism and cooperation
review.abstract: We propose a new solution concept for one-shot normal form games based on a principle that can be summarized as follows: players forecast how the game would be played if they formed coalitions and then they play according to their best forecast.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Since its inception by Morgenstern and von Neumann [Mo-vN44], the fundamental challenge of modern game theory has been to predict what actions a human player would apply in a strategic situation. A first prediction was suggested in an earlier paper by J. von Neumann [vN28] for two-person zero-sum games and then generalized to each finite game by J. Nash. Since then, Nash Equilibrium has certainly used the most remarkable and applied concepts of solution in game theory. Nevertheless, over the last sixty years it has been recognized that there are bad predictions for the human game and indeed a large number of experiments have been conducted for which it has not been dramaturgically possible to predict human behavior. There are many reasons for this failure; if there are multiple balances, it is not clear which we expect to play.

sections.text: In the previous section, we discussed a number of examples in which the cooperative equilibrium under the expected benefit theory satisfactorily predicts human behavior. On the other hand, since we work with profit functions, it is natural to use cumulative benefit theory instead of the expected benefit theory. But, before describing the cooperative equilibrium under the cumulative benefit theory, we will discuss a few examples in which the transition from the expected benefit theory to cumulative benefit theory depends on the cooperative benefit theory: they first decrease when the number of players increases, but then when the number of players is sufficiently large, they rise again. This behavior is not predicted by the cooperative equilibrium under the expected benefit theory, which predicts that contributions under the expected benefit theory decrease as the x ability increases. Nevertheless, this behavior is consistent with the cooperative equilibrium under the cumulative benefit theory.

metadata.abstractText: Over the years, numerous experiments have been accumulated to show that cooperation is not casual and depends on the payoffs of the game. These findings suggest that humans have attitude to cooperation by nature and the same person may act more or less cooperatively depending on the particular payoffs. In other words, people do not act a priori as single agents, but they forecast how the game would be played if they formed coalitions and then they play according to their best forecast. In this paper we formalize this idea and we define a new solution concept for one-shot normal form games. We prove that this cooperative equilibrium exists for all finite games and it explains a number of different experimental findings, such as (1) the rate of cooperation in the Prisoner’s dilemma depends on the cost-benefit ratio; (2) the rate of cooperation in the Traveler’s dilemma depends on the bonus/penalty; (3) the rate of cooperation in the Publig Goods game depends on the pro-capite marginal return and on the numbers of players; (4) the rate of cooperation in the Bertrand competition depends on the number of players; (5) players tend to be fair in the bargaining problem; (6) players tend to be fair in the Ultimatum game; (7) players tend to be altruist in the Dictator game; (8) offers in the Ultimatum game are larger than offers in the Dictator game. JEL Classification: C71, C72.
